awd_titl_txt: RUI: Confirmation of the roles of fungal genes in plant stress tolerance
awd_abstract_narration:
The 3-way symbiosis at the focus of this project is intriguing by virtue of the host plants gaining tolerance to soil temperatures of up to 125°F, a temperature at which most plants cannot grow. Plants survive this temperature due to their association with a particular fungus infected with a specific virus. Virally infected fungi living symbiotically with a host plant provide heat tolerance to a wide range of crop plants including tomato, corn, and rice. In a field trial, tomato plants harboring a fungal-viral symbiont showed improved growth and fruit production at elevated temperatures compared to non-infected plants. With the US economy losing more than $15 billion annually in crop production due to environmental factors, it will be potentially helpful to understand the mechanisms by which thermotolerance is induced in this virus-fugus-plant symbiosis. Insights gained from the research are likely to help in the development of methods to retain crop productivity in the face of high temperature stress. The project will provide hands-on multidisciplinary research training and educational opportunities for underrepresented minorities and first-generation college students at the University of West Alabama, a designated Minority Serving Institution. In addition, the project will include an educational outreach program for underprivileged K-12 students and adults through the Science Saturdays and Science Coffee Shop outreach programs, respectively. Finally, the physiological and molecular roles of fungal metabolites in stress tolerance will be of broad interest to the scientific community.

In the geothermal soils of Yellowstone National Park, where temperatures can reach 65°C, a 3-way mutualistic association has evolved among panic grass (Dichanthelium lanuginosum) and a fungal endophyte (Curvularia protuberata) bearing a mycovirus, Curvularia thermotolerance virus (CThTV), which allows the 3 organisms to cooperatively survive extreme temperatures.  Metabolic analyses showed significant changes during stress in our model system tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) infected with C. protuberata. The data collected in those analyses provide strong evidence that fungal trehalose and melanin are essential for the heat-stress tolerance mechanisms conferred by the 3-way symbiosis. In addition, CThTV contributes to thermotolerance via its interaction with a fungal translationally controlled tumor protein (TCTP) and catalase/peroxidase (KatG), which control fungal cell cycle and cellular redox, respectively. The hypotheses of this research are that C. protuberata carrying CThTV confers thermotolerance in plants via: 1) production of large quantities of trehalose, which is transported into plant tissues and functions as a signalling or osmoprotectant molecule to regulate plant biochemical processes during stress; 2) fungal melanin, which likely alters fungal cell walls to control trehalose transport into and accumulation in plant tissues during stress; and 3) CThTV, promotes thermotolerance by interacting with fungal TCTP and KatG to control fungal cell cycle and cellular redox during stress. In particular, the proposed research is designed to test the involvement of fungal trehalose, melanin, TCTP, and KatG genes in thermotolerant tomato associated with fungal-viral symbionts. The aims of this study are to: 1) knock down the trehalose, melanin, TCTP, and KatG genes in thermotolerant C. protuberata-carrying CThTV, thermotolerance will be completely abolished in trehalose or melanin synthesis knock downs, and reduced by knocking down TCTP or KatG expression; and 2) overexpress the same genes in non-thermotolerant C. protuberata without CThTV, plants are expected to gain thermotolerance characteristics in the case of trehalose and melanin biosynthetic gene overexpression, and exhibit improved thermotolerance in the case of TCTP and KatG overexpression.

por.por_cntn:
Most crop plants cannot cope effectively with environmental stress, such as high temperature that adversely affects plants causing severe cell injury, cell death and ultimately leading to growth inhibition and reduced yield. In nature, almost all plants develop symbiotic relationships with fungal endophytes, which provide them with improved abiotic and biotic stress tolerance. In addition, mycoviruses (viruses infecting fungi) contribute to plant adaptation to heat stress provided by fungal endophytes.  In the geothermal soils of Yellowstone National Park, a panic grass (Dichanthelium lanuginosum) is able to grow in soil temperatures over 50°C because of a symbiotic association with Curvularia protuberata that harbors a double-stranded RNA virus named Curvularia thermotolerance virus (CThTV). All partners (the plant, the fungus and the virus) are needed together to survive temperatures above 38°C, forming a three-way symbiosis. The molecular mechanisms of the three-way symbiosis are unknown. Understanding the mechanisms by which endophytes/mycovirus provide abiotic stress tolerance is crucial for the potential application of the C. protuberata-CThTV symbiotic system in crop plants.

Intellectual Merit

In this study, we explored the potential involvement of fungal trehalose, translationally controlled tumor protein (TCTP) and a catalase/peroxidase (CAT) protein in controlling the thermotolerance acquired via the three-way symbiosis system.

We tested the role of these candidates via knock-down of the trehalose, TCTP, and CAT genes in C. protuberata-carrying CThTV (AN), which is capable of providing thermotolerance, to figure out if the plant thermotolerance will be reduced or abolished. Similarly, we overexpressed the same genes in non-thermotolerant virus free C. protuberata (VF) to find out if the plants will gain better thermotolerance upon overexpression of these genes.

After colonizing tomato plants with VF overexpressing TSP1 or TSP2 and heating the soil to 55oC for 7 days, the plants showed improved survival by respectively 41% and 20% compared to non-transformed VF fungi.  Similarly, knock-down of TSP1 and TSP2 genes in AN reduced the survival rate by respectively 8% and 50% compared to the non-transformed AN control treatment. In addition, overexpression of the TCTP and CAT in VF increased plant survival by individually 61% and 32% compared to the non-transformed VF control treatment.  Knock-down of these genes in AN reduced plant survival by 8% and 50%, respectively. Through this award, we proved that trehalose, TCTP and CAT are involved in the molecular mechanisms controlling the three-way symbiosis system

Additionally, we identified more than 400 fungal endophytes harbored by wild plants growing under various environmental stressed conditions (poor soil and high salinity) in Alabama. Several of these endophytes are being tested for their beneficial role in improving crop productivity under greenhouse and field trails.

Broader Impacts

Through independent research projects and summer internships, the project trained 38 undergraduate students (mostly minority students) and one high school student. Seven of the undergraduate students transitioned to graduate school, eight joined the workforce in biology-related jobs, the remainder undergraduates are in the process of finishing their degrees, and the high school student joined our college in 2018. Furthermore, through class-based research focused on the discovery of fungal endophytes, the project served 260 undergraduate students (65% of them are African Americans and/or women). Additionally, the project supported four graduate students who obtained a Masters in Conservation Biology or Masters in Art of Teaching (thesis-track). All graduate students are holding professional biology-related jobs, including science teachers. All students received hands-on training in plant physiology and molecular biology and learned how to develop a hypothesis, experimental planning, evaluation and interpretation of results, and finally deriving conclusions from the results.  Undergraduate and graduate students made over 50 presentations in local, regional, and national conferences. 

The project outreach to K12 students was conducted through the Science Saturdays program led by the PI. The project offered a total of 24 different workshops for K12 students from around the area, with the majority of them being minority and underserved. These workshops provided 500 students from 47 schools from 11 Alabama and Mississippi counties with opportunities to experience hands-on learning activities in science. This is a rewarding program that made a difference in many K12 students’ lives. For example, a current UWA student and former Science Saturdays attendee describes her experience with the program as “I loved Science Saturdays, my dad drove me for more than an hour from to attend these events. I would not be a sophomore at UWA majoring in biology if it was not for Science Saturdays. It taught me the interior components of plants, animals, and fungi. Now I get to volunteer helping when Science Saturdays is offered, a great way to give back to my community."
